A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Product of Ideals explicitly mentions that the ideals, denoted as \(\mathfrak{a}\) and \(\mathfrak{b}\), are within a ring \(R\). Ideals are specific subsets of a ring that are closed under addition and under multiplication by any element of the ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring is fundamental to the definition of ideals. Without the structure of a ring, the operations and properties that define what an ideal is (and consequently, what the product of two ideals is) cannot be established. Thus, the concept of a ring is necessary for the definition of the Product of Ideals to make sense.
